stem: The nurse is caring for a client with liver cirrhosis who is receiving lactulose. Based on the provided information, what actions are most important for the nurse to take? For each action, indicate the potential condition and the parameter to monitor.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR: Patient is a 68-year-old male with liver cirrhosis, admitted for increased confusion and elevated ammonia levels. 
07:05 Pt received lactulose 30 mL PO at 06:00. Pt is somnolent but arousable to verbal stimuli. 
07:10 Noted 3 episodes of watery stools since midnight. Abdomen is soft with normoactive bowel sounds in all quadrants. 
07:15 Skin turgor is slightly diminished. Mucous membranes are dry. Urine output has decreased to 20 mL/hr for the past 2 hours. 
07:20 Notified the provider of the changes in mental status and increased frequency of bowel movements. New order received. 
07:25 Will continue to monitor mental status, stool frequency, and fluid balance per orders. Patient education regarding lactulose side effects provided to family. Bedside commode available. Fall precautions in place. 
07:30 Documented vital signs and lab results in EHR. Will continue to assess and document findings.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Appears somnolent, arousable to verbal stimuli. Skin: Dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor. Abdomen: Soft, normoactive bowel sounds in all quadrants. Neuro: Disoriented to time and place.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: 1. Administer lactulose 30 mL PO q6h. 2. Monitor mental status q2h. 3. Monitor stool frequency and consistency. 4. Maintain strict I&O. 5. Monitor serum electrolytes daily. 6. Fall precautions.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Lactulose 30 mL PO q6h PRN for elevated ammonia. Last dose given 06:00.

actions.text: Assess for signs and symptoms of dehydration.
Hold the next dose of lactulose.
Administer a dose of lactulose as prescribed.
Encourage increased oral fluid intake, if tolerated.

rationale.correct: The client is showing signs of hypovolemia due to excessive stooling from lactulose therapy. Assessing for dehydration and encouraging fluid intake are crucial to prevent further complications. Monitoring serum electrolytes is vital as dehydration can lead to electrolyte imbalances, especially hypokalemia and hyponatremia. Monitoring urine output provides valuable data on fluid balance and kidney function.
rationale.incorrect: Holding lactulose (a2) may be necessary if hypovolemia is severe, but it doesn't address the immediate need for rehydration. Administering lactulose (a3) would worsen the hypovolemia. Hemodialysis (a5) is not indicated at this time as the primary issue is fluid loss. Hepatic encephalopathy may be a concern, but the immediate threat is hypovolemia. Monitoring mental status (p2) is important for hepatic encephalopathy but less directly related to hypovolemia. Abdominal girth (p4) is more relevant to ascites, not dehydration. Stool frequency (p5) is already known to be high.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Assessing for dehydration signs (poor skin turgor, dry mucous membranes) is critical in a client with increased stool output. Hypovolemia can lead to electrolyte imbalances. Monitoring electrolytes helps guide fluid and electrolyte replacement therapy.

clinicalPearls: Lactulose reduces ammonia levels by promoting its excretion through stool. However, excessive lactulose can cause severe diarrhea and dehydration.
When administering lactulose, closely monitor the client for signs of dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, especially hypokalemia and hyponatremia.
Always assess the client's fluid status and adjust lactulose doses accordingly. If dehydration occurs, consider temporarily holding or reducing the dose.

questionTrap.trap: Many students may focus solely on the elevated ammonia levels and choose actions related to hepatic encephalopathy without recognizing the immediate threat of hypovolemia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess all available data, including vital signs, physical exam findings, and lab results, to identify the most pressing clinical issue. Prioritize interventions based on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and the severity of the client's condition.
